security_audit.summary: A documentation-focused skill containing a Python helper script that reads/writes local markdown files and executes git log commands for changelog generation. All capabilities are appropriate for a markdown documentation tool. No network calls, no credential access, and no system command injection vulnerabilities detected.

low_findings.title: Python helper script with file system access
low_findings.description: The skill includes a Python script at scripts/markdown_helper.py that reads and writes local files. The script opens user-specified markdown files for TOC generation (line 64-65), writes output files for changelog generation (line 231-232), and validates local links by checking file existence (line 271-273). This is legitimate behavior for a markdown documentation tool but represents filesystem access capability that could be used to read or write files within the user's project directory. An attacker could theoretically use this to read or modify files accessible to the user's project context, though the script is constrained to markdown processing workflows.

low_findings.title: Git subprocess execution for changelog generation
low_findings.description: The script uses subprocess.run() to execute git log commands (line 108) to extract commit history for changelog generation. The command runs: `git log --pretty=format:%H|%h|%an|%ae|%ad|%s|%b --date=short` with optional tag filtering. Command construction uses a list-based approach which prevents injection. While legitimate for changelog generation, subprocess execution is a potential risk factor that requires the git command to be available in the execution environment.

content.value_statement: Creating professional documentation is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides templates, best practices, and helper scripts for generating polished README files, changelogs, contribution guides, and technical documentation with consistent formatting and structure.
actual_capabilities: Generate professional README files with badges, sections, and code examples
Create changelogs automatically from git commit history
Build table of contents from markdown headers
Format technical documentation with syntax highlighting and tables
Write contribution guidelines with development setup instructions
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly - generates markdown text only
Requires git repository for changelog automation features
Helper scripts require Python 3.7+ to run locally

use_cases.title: Document code projects

use_cases.title: Produce documentation

prompt_templates.title: Basic README
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a professional README file for my project. Include a title with badges, brief description, table of contents, installation instructions, usage examples with code blocks, and license information.

prompt_templates.title: Changelog from git
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a changelog for my project. Use the git log to extract commits since the last release tag. Format entries using Conventional Commits categories like Added, Changed, Fixed, and Security.

prompt_templates.title: Contribution guide
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a CONTRIBUTING.md file for my open source project. Include code of conduct, development setup instructions, coding standards, commit message guidelines, and pull request process.

prompt_templates.title: API documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create API reference documentation for a Python module. Include function signatures with type hints, parameter descriptions, return values, usage examples, and error handling information.

best_practices: Start with a clear title and one-line description followed by badges showing key information
Include a table of contents for documents over 300 lines to improve navigation
Use consistent heading hierarchy and include code examples for every major feature
anti_patterns: Do not use generic titles like My Project without clear identification
Avoid wall-of-text paragraphs - break content into logical sections
Do not mix heading styles or skip levels in the document hierarchy

faq.question: Does this skill modify my files?
faq.answer: No. This skill generates markdown text content. The helper scripts in scripts/ can write files but must be run manually.

faq.question: What platforms support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for generating documentation in any markdown-supported environment.

faq.question: Can I generate changelogs without git?
faq.answer: The helper script requires git to extract commit history. You can manually write changelogs using the provided template.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill only processes text you provide. No data is sent to external services or stored beyond your session.

faq.question: Why are my badges not loading?
faq.answer: Badge services like shields.io require internet access. Check your network connection and verify badge URLs are correct.

faq.question: How is this different from other documentation tools?
faq.answer: This skill integrates directly with AI assistants to generate context-aware documentation using natural language prompts.
